meeting_annotations.speaker: Jordi Cabana
meeting_annotations.transcript: Single pass conversion okay. So you know when you look inside the reactor what is you know what is driving that that competition is that something that is as simple as reactor design or is it just that your catalyst cannot transform fast enough?
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: A document remains shared in a small window at the top of the screen. The content is static text. No changes are made during this segment.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Wilson Smith
meeting_annotations.transcript: It's reactor design and the electrolyte. So if you're doing CO2 even if you start with a basic electrolyte if you start to run it more than 10 or 20 milliamps it's going to become alkaline spontaneously. So it's the electrolyte consumption but then with the with the kind of transport control there are things like pressure drops that will change and it depends on if you're making CO2 to CO so a gas feedstock to a gas product the the pressure drop across your electrode will be small but if you want to make a liquid product you will create a much bigger pressure drop across your electrode and the effects down the channel will be much more significant. So it's there there's a lot of competing factors which is why I think you know CO2 electrolysis won't scale the same way that water electrolysis does. You know selectivity is not an issue for water electrolysis. Partial pressure differences across the electrodes is is managed very well and I think for for CO2 reduction it's so big you can make a gas you can make a liquid you can make lots of products they're much more sensitive to to changing their performance based on scaling relations.
